resource descriptions.descriptionText: PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Urachal cyst. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.
Medscape Reference provides information on this topic. You may need to register to view the medical textbook, but registration is free.
The Urology Care Foundation offers an information page on Urachal cyst. Please click on the link to access this resource.

The Monarch Initiative brings together data about this condition from humans and other species to help physicians and biomedical researchers. Monarch’s tools are designed to make it easier to compare the signs and symptoms (phenotypes) of different diseases and discover common features. This initiative is a collaboration between several academic institutions across the world and is funded by the National Institutes of Health. Visit the website to explore the biology of this condition.

overviewQuestion.answerText: A urachal cyst is a sac-like pocket of tissue that develops in the urachus, a primitive structure that connects the umbilical cord to the bladder in the developing baby. Although it normally disappears prior to birth, part of the urachus may remain in some people. Urachal cysts can develop at any age, but typically affect older children and adults. Urachal cysts are often not associated with any signs or symptoms unless there are complications such as infection. In these cases, symptoms may include abdominal pain, fever, pain with urination and/or hematuria. Urachal cysts may be monitored, or they may be treated with surgery to drain the cyst and/or remove the urachus.[1866][5889][13864]

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the signs and symptoms of a urachal cyst?
basicQuestions.answerText:
In most cases, urachal cysts are not associated with any signs or symptoms unless there are complications such as infection. Possible symptoms vary, but may include:[1866][8839]
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Fever
  • Abdominal lump or mass
  • Pain with urination
  • Urinary tract infection
  • Hematuria
In some cases, there is also an open connection between the bladder and the umbilicus (belly button), which is called a urachal sinus. This may cause drainage of urine from the belly button.[15230]

references.authors: Bagnara V, Antoci S, Bonforte S, Privitera G, Luca T, Castorina S
references.articleTitle: Clinical considerations, management and treatment of fever of unknown origin caused by urachal cyst: a case report

basicQuestions.answerText: A urachal cyst occurs when a pocket of air or fluid develops in the urachus. Before birth, the urachus is a primitive structure that connects the umbilical cord to the bladder in the developing baby. The urachus normally disappears before birth, but part of the urachus may remain in some people after they are born. This can lead to urachal abnormalities such as urachal cysts.[1866][8841]

basicQuestions.questionText: How is a urachal cyst diagnosed?
basicQuestions.answerText:
The diagnosis of a urachal cyst may be suspected based on the presence of characteristic signs and symptoms. The following tests may then be ordered to confirm the diagnosis:[8839][8841]
  • Ultrasound
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI scan)
  • Computed Tomography (CT scan)

references.authors: Bagnara V, Antoci S, Bonforte S, Privitera G, Luca T, Castorina S
references.articleTitle: Clinical considerations, management and treatment of fever of unknown origin caused by urachal cyst: a case report

basicQuestions.questionText: How might a urachal cyst be treated?
basicQuestions.answerText: Treatment of a urachal cyst may depend on whether or not the person is experiencing any symptoms. Sometimes these cysts are not treated but are monitored, particularly if there are no symptoms. In some cases, the urachal abnormalities resolve on their own without treatment. Because there is a small risk that a urachal cyst may become cancerous, surgery may be performed to completely remove the urachus. You can talk to your doctor about the risk of the urachal cyst causing infection or developing into cancer and balancing that with the risks associated with surgical removal.[1866][8839][8841][13864]

references.authors: Bagnara V, Antoci S, Bonforte S, Privitera G, Luca T, Castorina S
references.articleTitle: Clinical considerations, management and treatment of fever of unknown origin caused by urachal cyst: a case report

references.authors: Naiditch JA, Radhakrishnan J, Chin AC.
references.articleTitle: Current diagnosis and management of urachal remnants

basicQuestions.questionText: What is the long-term outlook for  a urachal cyst?
basicQuestions.answerText: The long-term outlook (prognosis) for a urachal cyst is generally good. In most cases, urachal cysts are not associated with any signs or symptoms unless there are complications such as infection. There are instances where urachal abnormalities resolve on their own. Because there is a small risk of urachal cancer, the entire urachus may be surgically removed. You can talk with your doctor about the risks associated with surgery. There is usually no need for follow-up or evaluation if the urachus is removed.[1866][13864]

references.authors: Naiditch JA, Radhakrishnan J, Chin AC.
references.articleTitle: Current diagnosis and management of urachal remnants

gardCases.abbreviatedInquiry: My stepson just found out he has a urachal cyst and his urologist told him it can become urachal cancer. Can a urachal cyst turn into urachal cancer? Would removing the cyst prevent him from getting the cancer?

caseQuestions.questionText: Can a urachal cyst cause urachal cancer?
caseQuestions.answerText: Yes, a urachal cyst can become urachal cancer, but this is a rare occurrence.[1866][5889] One research study showed that urachal cancer was not found in any children with urachal cysts; however, 25% of adults with urachal cysts were found to have urachal cancer. The authors of this study suggested that the longer the urachal cyst remained in the body, the greater the chance it could become cancerous.[5889]

references.authors: Ashley RA, Inman BA, Routh JC, Rohlinger AL, Husmann DA, Kramer SA
references.articleTitle: Urachal anomalies: a longitudinal study of urachal remnants in children and adults

caseQuestions.questionText: How might a urachal cyst be treated?
caseQuestions.answerText: Treatment of a urachal cyst may depend on whether or not the person is experiencing any symptoms. Sometimes these cysts are not treated but are monitored, particularly if there are no symptoms. In some cases, the urachal abnormalities resolve on their own without treatment. Because there is a small risk that a urachal cyst may become cancerous, surgery may be performed to completely remove the urachus. You can talk to your doctor about the risk of the urachal cyst causing infection or developing into cancer and balancing that with the risks associated with surgical removal.[1866][8839][8841][13864]

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
